Name: Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A construction procedure for the installation of all conduits and pits shall be submitted to the Administrator at least 14 days prior to the commencement of installation. No excavation activity associated with the installation of conduits and pits shall commence until the expiration of the 14-day period.
Item Check - Witness Point & Hold Point

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Asbestos is suspected or found in existing installation, work at this site must be stopped immediately, and the finding must be reported to the principal immediately for their decision and instruction on the work to be carried out at the site.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All materials must comply strictly with the requirements of this Technical Specification. For all materials, a certificate of such compliance shall be provided to the Administrator before the materials are incorporated into the works
Excavation for underground conduits and pits

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Conduit runs and pit locations shall be set out and notice of such set out shall be provided to the principal at least 48 hours prior to the commencement of excavation. Construction shall not commence before the expirations of the period of notice.
Item Check - Witness Point & Hold Point
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The bottom of the trench shall be compacted as per Standard Drawing 1149 to form a firm uniform surface free from loose material.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Work shall not commence until it has been demonstrated to the Administrator that the proposed equipment can accurately install the conduit in accordance with MRTS140 Horizontal Directional Drilling (HDD) and Standard Drawing 1149 Installation of Underground Electrical and Communication.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The installation of conduits shall conform to the requirements of Standard Drawing 1149. The installation of communications conduits shall also comply with the requirements of AS/CA S009. Prior to installation, the Contractor shall inspect all conduit and conduit fittings to ensure that they are free of any defects that could damage the cables during installation. Conduits to be installed without dips/low points to ensure that drainage at pits operates as intended.

○ The conduits are not to be lower than the pit it connects to unless approved by the Principal. Road crossing installed by ‘boring’ conduit to be installed level to facilitate correct drainage of conduit.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - After installation and backfilling, the conduit and conduit fittings shall be proved by drawing a mandrel having a diameter of at least 95% of the internal diameter of the conduit. The mandrel shall have a length sufficient to allow it to pass around any bends in the conduit, but not shorter than 95% of the diameter of the conduit being tested

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Any joints made in the draw rope shall be capable of resisting the same tensile load as the draw rope without such a joint. The joint shall not appreciably increase the diameter of the rope.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Any alternative proposed conduit sealing system shall be fit for purpose, and a proprietary system, and shall be submitted to the Administrator for consideration and approval prior to commencement of the installation of any cabling.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The bottom of an excavation for a pit shall be compacted to at least 95% relative compaction.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Compact bedding material to density index 60.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The lowest open end of conduits installed in poles and other field equipment enclosures shall be at least 50 mm higher than the surrounding finished surface level.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Backfilling of trenches for conduits shall not commence until the conduit system has been inspected by the Administrator

○ Backfilling shall not commence until all the conformance and As Constructed survey requirements have been met as specified in Clause 11 and 12 of MRTS91, and notice of such works provided to the Administrator
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The Contractor must develop an Asphalt Quality Plan (AQP) for the asphalt work to the Administrator for consideration at least seven days prior to work commencing and must be implemented.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - For dense graded asphalt, the tensile strength ratio (TSR) must be ≥ 80% when determined in accordance with ATM 232 and the average tensile strength of the freeze / thaw group must be:

a) ≥ 500 kPa for mixes containing SBS based polymer modified binder (e.g., A10E, A15E and 
A20E), and
b) ≥ 600 kPa for mixes containing all other binders.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - At least seven days before asphalt is to be incorporated into the Works, the Contractor shall submit to the Administrator a copy of the mix design certificate(s) for each nominal size and type of asphalt mix to be incorporated into the Works.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The properties of asphalt mix must comply with Table 2.6.1 - Asphalt mix properties of LCC spec No. 13 Part 2.6.1 when tested in accordance with column 3, asphalt shall aslo comply with MRTS 30.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All asphalt shall be placed in accordance with design drawings and as per drawings GW001 & LS001

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Asphalt shall be produced by a registered asphalt manufacturer from the nominated asphalt plant in accordance with the nominated mix design for the Works. Asphalt shall not be incorporated into the Works until the Contractor has demonstrated to the Administrator that the underlying lots conform to the specified requirements

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - For asphalt placed over pavement constructed by others, the surface on which asphalt will be placed shall be tested for perceptible surface deformation by ‘proof rolling’ in the presence of the Administrator.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Unless otherwise approved by the Administrator, asphalt shall not be placed over pavement exhibiting significant perceptible surface deformation.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Existing substrate shall not be wet and shall be swept thouroughly to remove and loose or deleterious material

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The asphalt mix temperature is controlled so that it is between 135C and 175C when loaded into the delivery truck, the mix temperature is between 110C and 165C immediately behind the paver with compaction commencing before the temperature of the mix falls below a minimum of 95C.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Compaction is commenced as soon as possible after spreading, and is completed in the shortest possible time except in the event of significant deformation or an irregularity occurring under the action of the roller in which case, rolling is delayed
○ For compaction testing, a lot is the same as for a production lot and compaction testing is undertaken in accordance with Q302A, Q302B, Q306B and Q314.

○ After completion of each job, core samples are taken from the compacted asphalt at the rate of one core per 1000m2 of asphalt laid, but with a minimum of three cores per job, asphalt compaction shall be greater than 95%
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Lot Number established with the Lot boundaries of the works clearly defined for traceability within the works
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All services identified – shall be marked, potholed and/or protected as required
○ Permit to excavate issued by Project Engineer
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The minimum testing frequencies shall be as stated in Tables A.1 and A.2 of Appendix A.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Erosion and sediment controls in place
○ Due care taken to ensure native fauna is not harmed
○ Vibration and Air quality to be monitored as a direct result of construction activities
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The bottom of excavations shall be trimmed to the tolerances specified in Clause 6 and any loose material removed from the surface.

○ The existing soil is compacted to 95 percent relative dry density standard compaction, for a depth of 300mm below the sub-grade and care is taken to ensure that the topsoil and organic material is removed and replaced with approved selected material for a depth of 500mm and compacted to 95 percent relative dry density standard compaction where the sub-grade passes through the natural surfaceat the ends of the excavation or anywhere in cross-section.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Unsuitable material below the level of the sub-grade in an excavation is:

(a) removed and run to spoil in accordance with section 12.1 of Specification 1,or replaced with select backfill in accordance with section 8.3–Selected gravel fill or selected backfill of this standard specification;
(b) compacted to 95 percent relative dry density standard compaction
Unsuitable Material Below Lines of Cuttings

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Material below the finished lines and levels of cuttings, which is Unsuitable Material in accordance with the provisions of Clause 9.2, shall be removed and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Clause 9.4.

○ Where Unsuitable Material has been removed, the excavation shall be backfilled to the finished surface level with appropriate fill material as specified on the drawings or in accordance with Clause 18 and 19.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Once Works are completed to Subgrade Level (including all Subgrade treatments), an As Constructed Survey of the bottom of the excavated area shall be undertaken as specified in MRTS56 Construction Surveying and notice of such Works provided to the Administrator.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Lot closure requires all relevant information to be attached to the Conformance Report this includes a Lot Plan, Survey Report, Hold Points/Approvals & any supporting documentation
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)
ITP - Geotextiles for paving applications - Rev1
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Geotextile to be used as specified in approved drawings
Storage, packaging and identification on site
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Geotextiles shall be stored under protective cover or wrapped with a waterproof, opaque UV protective sheeting to avoid any damage prior to installation.

○ Geotextiles shall not be stored directly on the ground or in any manner in which they may be affected by heat. The method of storage shall be in accordance with any other recommendations set by the manufacturer.
○ The protected geotextile rolls shall be clearly labelled showing manufacturer, type of geotextile and batch number identification number

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A construction procedure detailing all work described in this Technical Specification shall be prepared. The construction procedure shall be consistent with the guidelines set out in the Transport and Main Road’s Pavement Rehabilitation Manual April 2012, Sections 4.4.6 to 4.4.6.8.
○ The proposed construction procedure shall be submitted to the Administrator at least 14 days prior to the commencement of any works related to the placement of paving geotextile(s)

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - No works related to the placement of paving geotextile(s) shall commence until the construction procedures have been approved by the Administrator and the Administrator has given the Contractor permission to proceed.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - At least 14 days prior to the proposed ordering date of any geotextile, the Contractor shall submit to the Administrator a copy of the proposed manufacturer’s technical data sheet and a sample of the proposed geotextile from the manufacturer demonstrating compliance with this Technical Specification
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The Contractor shall not order any geotextile prior to the acceptance of that geotextile by the Administrator.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - With each batch of geotextile incorporated in the Works, a certificate of compliance stating that the geotextile complies with all the requirements of this Technical Specification as appropriate to the application, together with test results reported on NATA endorsed test documents, shall be included in the Quality Records

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Spraying of bitumen or placement of geotextile shall not commence until the temperature of the surface of the pavement is above the temperature specified in MRTS11 Sprayed Bituminous Surfacing
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All concrete works are to be installed in location and noted on a lot map attached to this document and accordance with the specified drawings:

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All mix designs shall be submitted to the administrator prior to works beginning if insufficient testing history is available for the specified mix from an approved supplier, preliminary mixes for all grades of concrete are designed, made and tested.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Concrete Mix designs are approved prior to the usage in any works.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Where the bottom of an excavation is free of rock or a rock bar the existing soil is compacted to 95 percent relative dry density standard compaction, for a depth of 300mm below the sub-grade

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All steel reinforcement that will be used in concrete works shall be inspected and approved by the local government prior to the placement of concrete, all formwork shall be inspected and checked against formwork checklist. When forms appear to be unsatisfactory in any way, either before or during the placing of concrete, the work does not proceed until the defects have been corrected to the approval of the local government.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Contraction joints:
(a) are provided at centres matching the width of the footpath and not more than 3.0 metres;
(b) are formed by a jointing tool;
(c) do not exceed 35mm in depth or 6mm in width;
(d) are at right angles to the edge of the path.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Expansion joints:
(a) are placed at 15 metre centres except for 2.0m footpath which can be 16m to match dimension multiplier;
(b) are at right angles to the edge of the path;
(c) extend for the full depth of the concrete path and are 10mm in width.
○ All expansion joints shall be as per LCC specifcations or where specified in standard darwings.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All concrete poured on site shall be slump tested by a NATA certified testing contractor, all slump testing values shall be recorded by a pour record sheet and provided to the administrator with the submission of the lot. All slump values shall comply with table 2.4.1 under Standard Specification 7. All concrete shall be tested for strength, concrete is sampled and tested in accordance with AS 1012.1-1993 Methods of testing concrete - Sampling of fresh concrete, by an approved NATA registered laboratory and the results are provided to the local government.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Where the ambient temperature is likely to exceed 30°C, all practical precautions are taken to maintain the concrete at a temperature not exceeding 30°C at the time of placing to prevent shrinkage, settlement and presetting cracks. No concrete with a temperature higher than 30°C is placed unless otherwise approved by the local government.
○ Ready mixed concrete is placed and compacted within 1 hour 15 minutes of charging the mixer for concrete temperatures up to 30°C and within 30 minutes of charging the mixer.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All surfaces of concrete that are exposed to view in the completed structure are finished such that:

(a) Immediately after the removal of forms, all fins and other projections are ground off, all pockets and honeycombs are cleaned and filled with a stiff cement mortar having the same proportion of cement and sand as the original concrete, and the surface of the patch is ground flush;
(b) Decks are roughened slightly by brooming or other approved method before initial set;
(c) Kerb and channel, invert crossings, vehicle crossings and industrial crossings are finished with an approved steel finishing tool;
(d) Footpaths and pram ramps are finished with a wooden float and broomed.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Concrete surfaces are kept moist by spraying with an approved curing compound, or water sprays or wet sand in which case the surfaces are kept moist 24 hours a day for the full period specified without any breaks at weekends or holidays. Curing is commenced immediately on completion of the finishing of exposed surfaces or within 30 minutes of removal of the forms from other surfaces.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Where tolerances are not stated in the approved drawings for any individual structure or feature thereof, deviations from established lines, grades and dimensions are not greater than the tolerances listed in Table 6.4.1–Tolerances of this standard specification and are applied to the completed work.
○ Size of member or thickness of slab: +7mm, -0
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - No extra water is added to the concrete on site unless:
(a) the amount of the water being added is measured and recorded;
(b) the concrete is thoroughly remixed and a slump test taken to ensure the consistency is still within the specified limits in this standard specification.
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)
ITP - Installation of Kerb and Channel - Rev1
Prompting Name: ITP - Installation of Kerb and Channel

Name: Installation of Kerb, Channel & Kerb and Channel

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Kerb and channel complies with standard drawing number R-0080 and is one of the following profiles: B1, B2, SM5, M3, Median and Invert, and must be wet mix unless otherwise approvd by local government
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Concrete for kerb and kerb and channel is 32 MPa strength grade complying with the requirements of AS 1379-2007:
○ The slump values of the concrete are machine finished (wet kerb)—12mm minimum—40mm maximum.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Where pavement thickness exceeds 175mm in depth, the pavement extends under the kerb where the pavement thickness does not exceed 175mm in depth, the kerb and channel is firmly bedded on 100mm road base aggregate compacted to 95 percent modified dry density as required under AS 1289.0-2000 Methods of testing soils for engineering purposes - General requirements and list of methods. No concrete is placed until the foundations have been approved by the local government.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The concrete kerb or kerb and channel joins neatly with the existing kerb or kerb and channel over a minimal transitional length of 2 metres

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - In the case of kerb, a joint is cut and cork jointing is inserted every 20 metres with a cut joint midway between cork joints and jointing is placed in such a manner as to dissect the kerb for its full thickness.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A contraction joint is provided at 4 metre centres which is finished square and at right angles to the section of kerb or kerb and channel. The kerb or kerb and channel at a contraction joint is guillotined to the full depth of the concrete and re-finished with a jointing tool to form neat joint lines not exceeding 3mm in width and 6mm in depth

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The horizontal and vertical alignments of kerb, channel and/or kerb and channel shall not vary from those specified by more than ± 10 mm provided that the difference between the deviations from the correct levels at any two points 30 metres apart does not exceed 30mm.
○ Crossfall is maintained within +/- 0.50 percent of the design

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Notwithstanding the allowable tolerances, the invert of the channel is finished true to grade and alignment and channelling in which water is found to pond is not accepted and is removed immediately
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Alll topsoil imported to site shall comply wiht the following below
(a) is a fine soil type in accordance with Table 6.2.1–Soil type by texture of this standard specification;
(d) complies with AS 4419–2003 Soils for landscaping and garden use;
(f) is free from Nut Grass (Cyperus rotundus);
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Soil is imported from a source approved by the local government or is provided from material upon the premises where approved by the local government.

○ Soil from the premises which is improved to comply with Table 6.2.1–Soil type by texture of this standard specification by the use of additives such as Gypsum, may be used as topsoil where approved by the local government.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Soil is spread such that:
(a) the finished surface of the soil is smooth, free of lumps and free draining;
(b) the finished surface levels allows for the settling and spreading of mulch;
(c) the soil is lightly compacted over the prepared sub-grade;
(d) in a grassed area the edge of the soil is feathered into undisturbed ground.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Where soil is next to a kerb, a path, a mowing strip or other hard paved surface:
(a) the soil is finished flush for a seeded grass area and bevelled below the abutting finished grade to allow for turf or mulch;
(b) the finished grade of the mulch is approximately 10mm below the abutting finished surface level;
(c) the finished surface level of the turf is flush with the abutting finished surface level;
(d) the finished surface level of a grass area, turf and a garden bed adjacent to a building or other structure is 125mm below the weepholes in the building or the structure.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Topsoil depth is 75mm as per contract drawing GW001
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Fertiliser is to be applied as per manufacturer's specification to ensure healthy long term growth.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A turf roll has a minimum soil thickness of 20mm.
(2) The turf is delivered to the premises within 24 hours of being cut.
(3) The turf is laid within 36 hours of being cut.
(4) Where the laying of the turf is delayed, the turf is:
(a) protected and watered to maintain its condition;
(b) not allowed to dry out at any stage from cutting to laying.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The premises is to be kept free of weeds and rubbish and any damaged, defective or stolen landscaping item is to be repaired or replaced.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All turfef areas are maintained through the maintenance period such that at the end of the establishment period a turfed area has 100 percent of turf coverage, the plant estabblishment period is a minimum period of 12 weeks from the date that PC is approved.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A grassed area is maintained during the maintenance period by:
(a) mowing grass to 50mm height when grass has grown no higher than 75mm and removing grass clippings from the landscape area or as otherwise approved by the local government;
(b) applying water at regular intervals to ensure ongoing healthy growth

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The Maintenance Program is to be prepared by the Contractor and submitted to the Superintendent for approval prior to commencement of work under the Contract and is to contian details about the frequency which the contractor proposes to carry out its obligation under section 7.4 SS 2
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All reinforced concrete pipes and pit shall be as per drawings unless an alternitive is approved, all pipes shall be laid in location and to levels specified in drawings.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Unless otherwise noted on the approved drawings all pipes are Class 2 and comply with the requirements of AS 4058–2007 and all matrial conformnace data shall be included in the lot submission to the administrator.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All RCP will be constructed as per IPWEA-STD-DS-030 which covers excavation, bedding material and backfilling
○ Bottom of excavation shall be compacted to a 95% standard compaction unless insitu material is rock for all excavations.
○ Backfill material shall be either 5 or 10mm aggregate.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Pipes are laid true to line and grade, and are free draining and firmly bedded and are laid from the discharge end upstream to the following tolerances:

○ For pipes up to and including 600mm diameter, the socketed end of the pipe is laid upstream and a shallow excavation is made under the socket of each pipe so that the pipe fully rests for its full length of barrel upon the bedding material in the trench.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Pipe is not to be backfilled without being inspected and approved by administrator.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Prior to incorporating any Backfill material into the Works, the Contractor shall submit stockpile or source tests results as specified in part 4 of Standard specification 3 and conforms with table 4.1.1 Bedding Material
Item Check - Hold Point/ Witness Point
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - backfilled with approved material of minimum 4 day soaked California bearing ratio of 15 and compacted to 100 percent standard compaction.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - The pipe bedding or box culvert bedding and the lower layers of backfill up to a point 300mm above the crown of the pipe or box culvert are carefully packed and rammed solidly in layers of 150mm, to 95 percent standard compaction as determined by AS 1289.1.1 - 2001 and Amendment 1- 2002 and Amendment 2 - 2008 Methods of testing soils for engineering purposes - General requirements and list of methods.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All pipes lines are subject to internal inspection and approval, the inspection of all pipes is carried out using a remote controlled video camera and is submitted to the local government before being accepted on-maintenance. A report on the findings of a remote controlled video camera inspection is to be submitted to the local government in an electronic format suitable for utilisation in “Sewer Rat” compatible applications. Pipes must not show clearly visible cracks of more than one millimetre for a length of 300mm or more on the inside.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A drainage structure includes all work and materials necessary for the construction of gullies, inlet pits and manholes, including excavation, concrete rendering and all necessary frames, curves, gratings, precast units and surrounds, precast troughs, chambers, lintels and shafts for side entry gullies, as specified in the approved drawings and standard drawings.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All materials used in insitu drainage structure will the N32 class concrete or otherewise specified.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - All concrete is placed in dry conditions and no concrete is placed until the formwork, falsework, and reinforcing materials have been inspected and approved by the local government.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Where the sides of the excavation are deemed to be in solid ground shafts may be constructed without the use of backforms, where concrete is placed without backforms the specified wall thickness is increased by 50mm minimum and not greater than 300mm of the design thickness. The finished concrete surface shall have smooth even and neat edges and will be shaped per the design intent.

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Upstream of each headwall, manhole, or gully (other than an end of line gully), a 3.0 metre length of 100mm diameter sub−soil drainage pipe is laid in the bedding material.

(a) Class 400 perforated corrugated PVC pipe Type 1 that complies with AS 2439.1−2007 Perforated plastics drainage and effluent pipe and fittings—Perforated drainage pipe and associated fittings and AS 2439.2−2007 Perforated plastics drainage and effluent pipe and fittings—Perforated effluent pipe and associated fittings for sewerage applications;
(b) fitted with an approved geotextile filter sock where sand bedding is used.
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A sub-soil drainage pipe is a class 400 perforated corrugated PVC pipe Type 1 in accordance with AS 2439.1-2007 Perforated plastics drainage and effluent pipe and fittings - Perforated drainage pipe and associated fittings.
○ The diameter of a sub-soil drainage pipe is a minimum of 100mm and the perforations do not exceed 1.1mm in width and 7.4mm in length.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Where a kerb and channel is constructed a sub-soil drainage pipe is constructed
(a) immediately below the back of the kerb in accordance with standard drawing IPWEAQ R-0140,
(b) at least 150mm below the finished sub-grade level

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A trench for a sub-soil drainage pipe is excavated to 50mm below the invert level of the sub-soil drainage pipe and have a gradient which is specified in the approved drawings or which is a minimum of 1 percent.
○ The excavated trench is to be a minimum of 100mm wider than the outside diameter of the sub-soil drainage pipe.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Fileter material shall be either 5mm or 10mm drainage aggregate as per standard drawing IPWEA - RS - 140

Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - A sub-soil drainage pipe: shall be connected to a gully pit, as specified in standard drawing IPWEAQ R-0140; or discharges to a culvert head wall or an open channel below the edge of the road shoulder or at the edge of an embankment.
(a) If a sub-soil drainage pipe is not connected into a gully pit or a culvert headwall, a concrete headwall is provided to the sub-soil drainage pipe.
(b) The headwall is at least 100mm thick and extends for a minimum of 150mm on all sides of the pipe.
(c) Where the outlet is through a batter, the surface of the headwall conforms to the batter slope.
Acceptance Criteria and Frequency - Add below:

(1) Where the excavation encounters ground water or other poor ground conditions, the depth of the bedding and surround material is increased to provide adequate support for the pipe as approved by the local government.
(2) If poor trench conditions exist, the pipe, or structure is supported by rock ballast which is:
(a) sound igneous or metamorphic material that does not disintegrate in water;
(c) completely wrapped in a non−woven geotextile fabric 1.9mm minimum thickness;
Final Sign off and Approval - Conformance with the Specification
Final Sign Offs (to be completed at closure of Lot)
